Description: Rectangular wooden coffin of Senku; yellow paint on a layer of plaster; single row of Hieroglyphic text in blue paint and a wedjat-eye panel; lacks lid; also eight linen mummy-wrappings. Mummy wrappings: A = complete cloth, stored as laundered; 8 layers sewn together at the fringe side. B = Longth length, torn across one end, tied at one time at the original corners, one with cord. The weave is plain [warp-faced simple tabby] and the threads are S-spun and S-spliced; the stitch gauge is warp c.16 ends per 10mm and weft c.6 picks per 10mm. The fringe is an inwards facing type, a maximum of 5cm in from the selvedge. C = One hemmed and one torn end; fringe; folded cloth. Maximum width not preserved. D = Half a cloth, not folded, light in colour; Deir el-Bahri type self fringe; starting border more New Kingdom type. Very worn; has been mended.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Information from Hero Granger-Taylor. Published: PM IV: p. 268
Bibliographic references: Zitman 2010 / The necropolis of Assiut: a case study of local Egyptian funerary culture from the Old Kingdom to the end of the Middle Kingdom (II, 129, 228)
